title: Will the United States and China sign a trade agreement before 1 July 2021?
preds: This should have been called months ago.  Only two days to go.
These types of deals take time. as far as this question is concerned, there is no more time.

With statements like this about Taiwan, - https://reut.rs/2T1jslz - the temperature between US and PRC is unlikely to cool enough for any possible discussions on a trade agreement in the next 7 days. Nor, for that matter will targeted sanctions like this; https://reut.rs/3h1r7Z3. China's response seems to confirm this; https://reut.rs/3d60CR9
Not a policy priority for administration on this time-scale.
Too close in timing. It might take divine intervention to make a trade agreement possible.
Timeframe simply too short relative to (deficiency of) current talks, political problems for Biden would seem to be massive, etc. Not a huge fan of literal 0%, but I think 1% is too high.
unless things drastically change in the next 3 weeks. I don't see this happening in the questions time frame.
The alaska meeting was rough and no future plans have been set. I am bearish towards this.

There has been some potential easing in the US / China relationship with some high level talks in the last 10 days; https://reut.rs/3pjBECH & https://reut.rs/34M2rhn That said, there seems little likelihood of any sort of agreement in the next 27 days. Hence, I retain my earlier forecast. @sebawi / @SE_Meyer / @Wildwood2000 you may find this interesting
updating forecast due to passage of time and no relevant actions.
Anything involving diplomacy with China in the short term is a non-starter, until the situation with the origin of COVID-19 is resolved or the Wuhan laboratory is cleared as the source.

As per US China Business Council President, preserving phase one trade deal and fast track negotiations are important. 
http://www.xinhuanet.com/english/2021-05/13/c_139942993.htm. Hence, before 1 July, it is too early to expect a trade agreement.
With sanctions still in place, it is not looking promising for a trade agreement.
The China / US atmosphere doesn't seem very conducive to any trade agreements being signed in the near term.
Got a bit behind updating this. Straight line of original would be 5% and noises pretty negative

Maintaining current forecast, however, unless there are secret trade negotiations occurring right now, it seems highly unlikely that an agreement will be signed before July 1st.  A trade agreement with China does not appear to be a priority for the Biden Administration and both parties in the Untied States appear to be supportive a taking a tough line against China.  Maintaining a 3% probability to account for the possibility that there are negotiations going on or something unforeseen that would result in a quick trade agreement.
A lot to be gained by biden admin, even if the agreement is light on substance.
Not likely. Current state is deteriorating due to Taiwan and South China sea issues.
Time is starting to run out for this outcome given current state of US-China engagement.

Increasing just a bit to reflect the fact that the Biden Administration seems to already be acting on its foreign policy agendas in spite of the assumption that they would take the first several months trying to orient themselves before making big moves. Secretary of State Blinken is already said to have had hard-line conversations with Chinese counterparts. However, because the tensions are high, maybe that will cancel out the early progress. I don't know how to factor this in but it seems Canada and Japan seem to be having new riffs with China. There are issues about Hong Kong as well. There is a CNBC headline, "U.S.-China trade relations remain strained as Biden team takes tough stance similar to Trump (March 20)," that in my interpretation could increase the odds of a new trade agreement. Most people thought Trump would not get a trade deal in with China, but it happened to most people's surprise. Therefore, if Biden is taking a similar approach to Trump, logically, based on this sole information, that Biden is equally likely to get it done. On the other hand, is there even a need to have a new agreement? I don't know. Someone spill the tea.
Still a lot of time for this to happen; reconfirming previous forecast.
Very unlikely at that moment, maybe will change as pragmatic diplomats will increase influence on the issue
China relations are in trouble after Anchorage meetings

Now, judging from the meeting of Alaska, the chances will be very rare.

No change in my forecast.  Breaking news confirms my 1% "yes" forecast previously.  Katherine Tai confirmed as U.S. Trade Representative today.  Her staff backgrounded the WaPo reporter on her priorities.[1]  None of them included new agreements with China: "Among her first tasks will be advising the president on what to do about existing tariffs on most imported Chinese products, presiding over enforcement of a new trade deal with Mexico and Canada, and seeking a negotiated end to a long-running commercial dispute with the European Union." [1] https://www.washingtonpost.com/business/2021/03/17/tai-trade-biden/

Probably unilateral deal only in limited scope. A good place to start would be standardization of radial tires.  So you can retread truck tires.  There are other theories of economics that can be incorporated.
Will update upward upon news of progress.

According to Kevin Rudd, China is waiting for US to determine the next step, very likely to be a tactic concession. And the waiting period will be half a year. So there is still a probable agreement to be signed.
https://www.foreignaffairs.com/articles/united-states/2021-02-05/kevin-rudd-usa-chinese-confrontation-short-of-war

On the strategic side, the current US administration will be more amenable to new trade agreements with China (https://www.eastasiaforum.org/2021/02/15/will-bidens-america-change-course-on-china-and-trade/). However, the phase 1 agreement signed by the Trump 'failed' because China went slow with the purchase commitments (https://www.piie.com/blogs/trade-and-investment-policy-watch/anatomy-flop-why-trumps-us-china-phase-one-trade-deal-fell).
Tactically, it will take a long time for any new trade agreements for the following reasons:
Biden's trade representative, Katherine Tai still awaits Senate confirmation. Her statement is China must deliver phase 1 commitments. This will delay start of any negotiation process. Hence, July is too soon to see any agreement.
From the Chinese perspective, one should also note that China has concluded a comprehensive trade deal with EU.

These deals tend to take a very long time, and I imagine Biden admin will approach things more deliberately than previous admin. Also this just really makes it unlikely they hammer something out in 5 months: https://www.reuters.com/article/us-usa-biden-china/biden-says-there-will-be-repercussions-for-china-over-human-rights-idUSKBN2AH0AC?il=0
Important consensus of other forecasters which tends more and more towards "no".

I am assuming rejoining the TPT pact is not included.  Otherwise, my estimate would be a lot higher.   Biden is not happy with China's theft of intellectual property, and I suspect Biden thinks China will keep stealing regardless of any trade agreement.  This makes a new treaty difficult.

Upcoming G7 meeting. How will the spread of COVID be dealt with?  How will COVID variants be dealt with? Will truth be told about “xyz”?  Will there be a comprehensive multilateral agreement on COVID eradication? Does the left hand know what the right hand is doing of many stake holders?  Curl that. Who’s coin should we flip?

With it reported that China is failing to meet its commitments in the Phase 1 Trade Deal ->
https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/business-55760992 And the Biden Administration reviewing the Deal ->
https://www.ft.com/content/166e648e-c382-40ab-9a29-a1fa75fbf35d It doesn't appear likely that a Trade Deal will be signed before 1/7/21.

China is a rare issue that unites the US political spectrum (for the left  = human rights, for the right = unfair business competition). Recent Biden-Xi call reveals the distance apart on many issues. Quote below suggests Biden admin would prefer to prioritise domestic economic 'wins'.   https://www.cnbc.com/2021/02/11/biden-says-china-will-eat-our-lunch-on-infrastructure.html
-10 as there seems to be no news on this. Initially I was picturing an agreement to make some initial cut in tariffs on both sides but so far it does not seem that Biden is intending to do this ASAP.

Very low probability event as the anti-China sentiment is very strong among both US parties. The Biden administration seems to be inclined not rush with easing the previous administration measures against China.

6th of the way through the time since my first prediction. Straight line would take it to 12.5%. Going for 14% as I was not really expecting much early on this front, but will drop quicker if there are no movements this month.
Updated with lower likelihood.  Rationale is the same as the original.

Being that the current Administrations stance on China still places The Peoples Republic of China as an imminent threat and peer competitor, this would be highly unlikely. Everything regarding China and also, everything regarding the US's National Security posture is under review by the current Administration, in order to verify what the past Administration had been doing . The question of the question here, is how this question will be resolved, what are the parameters that define a new trade deal, and would a reworking of the previous phase 1 trade deal be considered a new trade deal with regards to resolving this question. https://www.reuters.com/article/us-usa-trade-china-idUSKBN29Y2DV

Will Senator Mitch McConnell and his wife visit Hong Kong to have a meal before the end of February 2021?
Unlikely given the current agenda that Biden faces, resolving the pandemic etc.
Too soon, although Biden will try to push for some agreement this year.

Reasoning:  The People's Republic of China is currently on a global apology tour.  This question simply asks if a new trade agreement will be signed and does not require our input/prediction on their intent to honor the terms of any such agreement.

Since Biden Rescinds Trump Order Banning Chinese Communist Involvement In US Power Grid, the likelihood of an agreement is higher.
https://thenationalpulse.com/news/biden-revokes-trump-energy-eo/

Thanks to @jayb 's finding (https://www.reuters.com/article/us-usa-biden-yellen-trade/u-s-treasury-pick-yellen-says-domestic-investment-needed-before-new-trade-deals-idUSKBN29Q2RZ), I believe there's no chance the Biden administration will embark on another trade war with China soon, they will first focus on domestic issues. Since the covid crisis is not going to be terminated before July, I don't expect any change.

,.Also noting Janet Yellen's comments about the Biden admin. likely prioritizing domestic investment before making trade deals: https://www.reuters.com/article/us-usa-biden-yellen-trade/u-s-treasury-pick-yellen-says-domestic-investment-needed-before-new-trade-deals-idUSKBN29Q2RZ
Yellen's comment on future China policy and reasons behind.

https://www.theguardian.com/world/2021/jan/20/european-leaders-hail-new-dawn-for-ties-with-us-under-biden But since Biden's top diplomat said being tough to China is right , I would keep the score unchanged.
https://asia.nikkei.com/Politics/International-relations/Biden-s-top-diplomat-pick-says-Trump-right-to-be-tough-on-China
it will take too much time for the new administration to settle in, clean up Trumps mess, deal with covid19 and start drafting any such agreement
No many people talk about this at this time, if it happens would be more probably on the second half of the year.
Trade deals take years and Biden will be busy with the transition from Trump and his impeachment. Biden is also pressured to be tough on china.

Unlink Trump, Biden doesn't have the "burden" of protecting US labor workers at home,  big tech and wall street all want an agreement with China.
As a new president, Biden would certainly undo some of the Trump's achievements,  a completely different trade agreement that get signed soon is an good option for him.
Traditionally, Democratic party has a better relationship with China

A comprehensive agreement in the next six months is unlikely, but there are Obama era initiatives that could be unmothballed, multilateral agreements that might get unstuck, and most likely rollbacks of elements of Trump's trade war that only caused the U.S. harm. Not sure if the latter would count as "signing" an agreement though. The Phase One agreement, deescalating the trade war, happened fairly quickly.
Biden has bigger priorities in year 1

Who won the trade war? 

"When a country (USA) is losing many billions of dollars on trade with virtually every country it does business with, trade wars are good, and easy to win," reads a (now suspended) tweet from President Trump from March 2019. While there are a whole lot of metrics to measure the objective, nearly three years into the battle with China, who's up and who's down in the relationship? Before the dispute began, 23% of all American imports came from China, roughly as much as neighboring Canada and Mexico combined. U.S. goods trade deficit with China reached a record $419.2B in 2018, and while that shrunk to $345M the next year (roughly the same level as 2016), the overall trade deficit did not. Unilateral tariffs on China diverted trade flows to other countries, boosting U.S. imports from Vietnam, Malaysia, Taiwan and even Mexico. Economists have also found Chinese exporters generally didn't lower prices to keep their goods competitive, meaning tariff duties were mostly paid by U.S. companies and consumers, and for China, it mainly led to a loss in export value. Beijing also made an ambitious vow to import $172B worth of U.S. goods in specific categories in 2020, but through the end of November it had bought just 51% cent of that goal, in part due to the slump in energy prices and trouble with Boeing's planes. Moving jobs back home? Not really, but it's hard to measure. U.S. direct investment into China increased slightly from $12.9B in 2016 to $13.3B in 2019, according to the Rhodium Group, and more than three quarters of 200+ U.S. manufacturers in and around Shanghai surveyed in September said they didn't intend to move production out of China. While retaliatory actions have also weighed on U.S. farm purchases, Chinese companies did pay a record $7.9B in intellectual property payments to the U.S. in 2019, up from $6.6B in 2016, and its courts imposed some record-breaking fines on IP infringement. Recent quote from China's President Xi: "The world is undergoing profound changes unseen in a century, but time and the situation are in our favor... This is where our determination and confidence are coming from." Outlook: President-elect Biden will have to decide whether to keep up the trade war. In a recent interview, he said he would review the Phase One deal and wouldn't remove the tariffs immediately, but the conflict is quickly escalating. Sanctions and export restrictions imposed on Chinese-owned companies seem to be leading to a big conflict over technology, while getting tougher with Beijing on human rights abuses in Xinjiang and concerns over Hong Kong will make for a difficult balancing act.
New US administration is likely to revisit any preparatory work on a trade agreement. Starting anew takes more time.

Skimming through surface info, it appears the Biden admin will be prioritising the handling of Covid-19 and reestablishing relationships with alliance partners like the EU and NATO. The other side of this is China, who haven't felt the economic impact of the pandemic to the same level the US has, and according to some are "winning" the trade war. If the latter is true, or even if China perceive it to be true, then they will come to the table looking to extract a little more from the US, making the signing of a deal less likely.  Personally I think a deal will happen at some point before 2024, but not in this half of 2021.
Due to slowness that occurs in negotiating any trade deal, and also with the upcoming administration changeover, I do not anticipate a new trade agreement within this timeframe.

While I believe China will be a priority on Biden's foreign policy agenda, free trade agreements average 1.5 years to negotiate and 3.5 years to implement. The "Phase One" agreement the Trump administration signed in Jan 2020 took almost two years to negotiate. Slim-to-no chance that one will be concluded by 1 July 2021.
Biden administration will be motivated to fix prior trade agreements early in it's administration

President-elect Biden will not have enough time to renegotiate with China since a large chunk of his coming months of presidency will be focused on transition, the virus, and reunification of the divided country. Moreover, the situation is not favorable economically for the US to coerce China into a favorable agreement.

While I anticipate a rollback of Trump admin protectionism, a trade agreement is unlikely in this timeframe.  Unlikely due to:  
- US domestic political costs in dealing with China favorably
- US geopolitical fears of a rising China
- Bureaucratic slowness in negotiating any given trade deal (considering US, China, recent EU deal) 
- Time lost in Biden onboarding/acclimation process (1-3 months will be lost in friction before anything like this would be approached) 
- If Biden admin does focus on China trade, initial efforts will be on rolling back Trump "trade war" efforts (versus a new deal)

I am moving my forecast down for a few reasons.  One, my forecast was 2x as high as the majority of forecasters.  Two, many forecaster's linked articles that led me to the belief that my forecast was high. And Three, the political acrimony seems so bad in Washington DC and looks to only be getting worse. However, I will not go as low as many others because I believe President Elect Biden has stated that China will be on his radar early on.  I believe both parties do believes a new trade agreement is needed and in th interest of the country. This alone gives me hope that an agreement will be had
With a new administration, it will take more time than 1 July for a new phase of trade negotiations to conclude.

From economics we know that trading is better than not trading; also the results of the US presidential election shows that the US did not like that much being harsh with the Chinese. The large amount of money involved will quicken the negotiations, and a settling agreement is more likely than not to emerge in 6 months - with further agreements following later.
Trade talks take more than 6 months.
Normal trade negotiations take longer than six months. Trump might have done one that quickly, but even he didn't.

He <Biden> has already said he wouldn’t immediately lift the tariffs. “ U.S. trade czar Lighthizer’s advice for Biden on China: ‘Hold their feet to the fire.:

There's a chance of *an* agreement, but may not be a major one. I can envisage something targeted & minor occurring
It may well be in the works by mid year but getting it agreed and signed is a lengthier process.

These things take time and it probably is not on the top of Biden’s in tray. Also a tricky deal to do and Biden clearly agrees with Trunp about some of the issues with us China trade (even if the style of approach is very different). Feels like it is higher than 10% though. Deal done recently that would meet the criteria and clear Biden views some of the tariffs as counter productive.

The timeframe of this question dictates the answer.
New administration negotiators will not even be on-board for weeks/months.
Forecasting a snow ball fight on the White House lawn in July might have a better chance than this question.

I believe that the default position on whether or not an event will happen should be "No" unless and until more information is brought out. My thinking is that unless there is a reason to do "something", the status quo will remain unchanged. Here, there are some reasons to believe there will be a change between the USA and China regarding trade.  Chief among them being President-elect Biden being sworn into office within the month.  It is no secret that the Trump administration challenged China and sought  adversarial negotiating tactics regarding trade that included tariffs.  Biden's administration may seek to soften the negotiations in an effort to better the relationship with the Chinese.  However, the Biden administration will have several issues to deal with in the beginning of the term including intransigent Republicans and the more liberal wing of the Democratic party who want more of a say in Biden's administration.   These issues lead me to believe that a trade agreement being signed in the first 6 months of Biden's term is not good.  However, because it is in the interest of both Countries to have a deal done, I cannot say that it is 0.

That would be moving very fast, and it sounds like Biden intends to take it slow and attempt to work with allies on China policy. I'm going a little higher than the crowd though because I think the possibility of a phase 2 type deal is possible in the short term, tariffs are damaging to our economy and it would be beneficial to both sides to deescalate a bit. But while that's possible I think it's more likely that he doesn't move as fast as I would like on this.
I doubt a Republican led senate will willingly go along with anything a Democratic president does.

As per my forecast, I believe this won’t happen but need to think (1) perhaps a limited trade deal is possible (could dust off/renew some of the agreements China made re. American grain etc.) and (2) China might be willing to cede a bit given barrage of bad news - they need a reset to try and present a friendlier face to world, going to think/look into this more. Tangentially related (from Economist) - but note it took seven years:
“China and the EU struck an investment deal after seven years of negotiations. The treaty would, among other things, give European firms greater access to China’s automotive and health-care markets. Despite concern in some quarters over China’s abysmal human-rights record, the deal is expected to be ratified and could take effect in 2022.”

Considering the issues over Uighur Muslims, Hong Kong security laws and the Biden administration intention to rebuild bridges with Asian allies to stem the power of China, while maintaining trade war tariffs, an immediate rapprochement  with the Chinese leadership is not on the immediate radar. Also, the time expended in setting up meetings and preparation would not suggest an early trade agreement. https://www.cnbc.com/2020/12/03/biden-could-rebuild-trade-deal-with-asia-pacific-to-counter-china-piie.html  https://www.scmp.com/economy/china-economy/article/3112294/us-china-relations-biden-says-trade-war-tariffs-remain-place
China is under scrutiny from back business practices, to cyber attacks, being unable/unwilling to detach business relationships from politics & communist rule.

It would be highly unusual for a U.S. administration to sign a trade agreement in its first six months, especially one staffed by competent and experienced diplomats and trade negotiators.  A normal administration will likely spend the first six months doing a policy review and gaining interagency consensus for agreement objectives and the strategy to get there.

Unlike EU, USA just might show some backbone and challenge Chinese leadership on human rights issues, violation of the one country two systems framework in HK, and general Chinese military expansion in the region. If a trade agreement accelerates the relocation of supply chains to China, there should not be an incentive for US Government to sign an agreement that leads to further industrial decline, loss of jobs, etc.

If Biden is confirmed as President definitively in January, it looks like he is going to look for a strategy with China that aligns US allies as well.  I do not believe this will be accomplished by July 1, 2021.  See article below: https://m.economictimes.com/news/international/world-news/biden-would-not-immediately-remove-phase-1-trade-agreement-with-china-nyt/amp_articleshow/79525034.cms

too much bad blood and not enough time to repair the relationship
incoming administration seems to be focused on domestic agenda and likely will let international status quo (China, Russia, Iran etc) slide while the domestic constituencies are satisfied

A bilateral trade agreement has been given a seemingly low priority on the President Elect’s publicly acknowledged agenda. Instead, the incoming administration has stated that they do not plan on lifting tariffs and is looking to encourage the EU into delaying and ultimately reversing course on a China deal in order to increase Western leverage against China on a united front. With these variables and complexities at play, it makes the prospects of a US-Sino trade deal to come about within 6 months of Biden taking office even more remote.    https://www.scmp.com/economy/china-economy/article/3112294/us-china-relations-biden-says-trade-war-tariffs-remain-place
https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2020-12-22/biden-camp-adds-pressure-on-eu-to-hit-the-brakes-on-china-deal
It won't be like the 1990s, but some low level trade deal will be used to leverage other issues with China and at the same time reverse some Trump policies that are tough on American farmers.
Biden will be looking for an opportunity to de-escalate and modify many of Trump's policies while negotiating with a new administration gives China the opportunity to save face.

It is clear the Biden team is looking to get a set of allies and deal with some of the advantages given to China, the old frame to get China from 3rd world to leader of the world has changed the dynamics of policy towards China. The present US approach is that can act alone, but as such approach is flawed and misses the reality on the ground. China has moved at the speed of light to exercise its leadership power, there is only one way to level the playing field with China and that requires alliances, thus more time to frame and apply.
I am thinking crops will be a likely trade agreement
this will avoid China from not infecting the World again. Time to learn Mandarin

i / The Biden administration will want to do a careful analysis of its options for a trade deal with China before entering a negotiation phase ; ii/ Biden has insisted on first breathing new life into the American industrial sector and in this context a China trade deal does not appear as a priority for his administration in the short term.

As a result of the US presidential transition, and its reported difficulties it is unlikely that the Biden administration will hit the ground running with regard to Chinese relations. Additionally, the new administration has voiced concerns over a potential EU-China deal as reported on 22 Dec 20. Not likely too many issues for Biden which he will want ally participation in.

Also, given the other China related issues on their plate hard to see how finding an agreement on trade fits in at the moment.  https://www.cnbc.com/2020/12/10/biden-to-name-katherine-tai-us-trade-representative.html

The Biden Administration needs about 100 days to establishing itself. Many problems by edicts create the Sitting President in this running period which President Elect Biden MUST ALL ERADICATE. The US voters in Georgia have it in their hands to elect two additional Democratic Senators for Senate, then the Vice President can create a Democratic majority in Senate. Otherwise nominations of Biden’s personnel can be blocked or stalled by Republicans in Senate. All that will delay foreign affairs by President Elect Biden.

Biden will be too wrapped up with restoring the US economy to attempt to repair the damage wrought by the Trump policies with China.  China currently is winning and not suffering at all from Trump's approaches and will be unwilling to meet with Biden despite their former close relationship.

https://www.piie.com/blogs/trade-investment-policy-watch/how-long-does-it-take-conclude-trade-agreement-us 5 exceeded 20 months and 24 days.
U.S and China sign before 1/7/2021 = 65% = (20-5)/20 However, given these negotiations weren't with the biggest economies in the world nor strategic rivals as is the case with the U.S and China, I would expect the negotiations to be more challenging and take longer. U.S and China sign before 1/7/2021 = 40% <- 65%
An agreement may come to pass but the timeline from inauguration to July 1 seems to short for this to occur.
With new US Administration starting in January it would be very quick to arrive at another agreement (or any sort) with China by July.
